Governance Update: Lido V3 Mainnet Release

The onchain vote to activate Lido V3 Phase 1 (Soft Launch) on mainnet is now live.

This proposal marks a major milestone in the evolution of the Lido protocol.

https://t.co/IvblN2q9tN
What does this vote enable?

Approval will activate Lido V3 Phase 1 (Soft Launch), introducing stVaults: non-custodial, modular staking vaults that let stakers choose specific operators or strategies built around stETH.

Phase 1 soft launch is designed for early adopters and partners, prioritizing security while preparing for the full public launch in January 2025.
Lido V3 lays the foundation for:
‚Ä¢ Greater protocol flexibility and composability
‚Ä¢ Clearer separation between infrastructure and product layers
‚Ä¢ A scalable framework for future staking innovation across Ethereum

This vote is the first step in bringing that architecture live.
Additional onchain vote now live: #195 (Omnibus Proposal)

A second proposal accompanies the V3 release, covering a set of operational and treasury updates, including:
‚Ä¢ Curated Module fee adjustments
‚Ä¢ Increasing the SDVT module stake share limit
‚Ä¢ Setting A41 soft target validator limit to 0
‚Ä¢ Resetting the Easy Track TRP limit
‚Ä¢ Adding sUSDS to the Allowed Tokens Registry and enabling Easy Track transfers
‚Ä¢ Tracking the EVM Script Executor in Aragon Finance
‚Ä¢ Transferring MATIC from the Lido Treasury to the LOL multisig

More info: https://t.co/zdGbDKYrSC
Lido DAO members are encouraged to review both proposals and cast their votes.

Deadline: Thu, Dec 18, 12:04 UTC (main phase)

Trustlessness demands no unverifiable outcomes.

Software provenance has relied on social assumptions, but Proof of Build anchors it with verifiable onchain proofs.

A deeper dive into the 7-step workflow ‚Üì 
Step 1: Initiation

A developer commits code, and the changes are pushed to a repository in the build environment. 
Step 2: Artifact construction

The CI/CD pipeline compiles the binary and generates an SLSA provenance file, signing it via the Sigstore infrastructure. 
Step 3: Ingestion (zkVM input)

The zkVM guest program takes in:

‚ñ∂Ô∏é SLSA provenance bundle
‚ñ∂Ô∏é Pinned Sigstore trust roots (Fulcio CA, TSA public keys)
‚ñ∂Ô∏é Timestamping (TSA or Rekor transparency logs)
‚ñ∂Ô∏é Expected policy (optional, e.g., allowed build digests) 
Step 4: Execution

Inside the zero-knowledge environment, the guest program performs steps to verify the signatures, certificate chain, and timestamps.

A ZK-SNARK proof is generated to prove that the provenance verification succeeded. 
Step 5: Onchain submission

The succinct ZK proof is submitted to the Ethereum smart contract. 
Step 6: Attestation

The smart contract validates the proof math and emits a verified event containing the build results. 
Step 7: Final trust verification

The downstream verifier consumes the onchain event to trust the artifact.

What is @NEAR_Intents?

The tech revolutionizes blockchain interactions by shifting from traditional transaction models to an intent-based paradigm, where users and AI agents simply express desired outcomes. Like swapping tokens across chains or executing complex trades, without needing to handle the underlying steps. 

At its core, the system operates on the @NEARProtocol, leveraging smart contracts to orchestrate these intents in a scalable, extensible manner that breaks down "walled gardens" between chains. 

Here's how it works:

1) Intent Creation: Submit signed goals (e.g., "swap ETH for USDC") via natural language/APIs; broadcast to network, no bridges needed.

2) Solver Competition: Solvers parse intents, aggregate on/off-chain liquidity, compete via RFQ for best quotes; monitor/exclude poor performers for efficiency beating Binance 50%+ of time on asset price.

3) Execution: Settle via NEAR verifier (2-3s finality). Chain Signatures equip contracts with keys via MPC for cross-chain control/confirmation (e.g., Zcash/Bitcoin), no exposed keys or bridges; protects from MEV/failures. 

You now have unified seamless blockchain experiences at scale.

Credit to @therollupco, @chronear, @alexauroradev for letting the world know.
